Award.AwardTitle: Detection of Distributed Static and Dynamic Loads with Electrolyte-Enabled Distributed Transducers in a Polymer-Based Microfluidic Device

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This objective of this award is to develop a fundamental understanding of the performance of a polymer-based microfluidic device with Electrolyte-Enabled Distributed Transducers (EEDTs) that can detect distributed loads. The novelty of this EEDT device lies in its configuration, a single deformable polymer microstructure integrated with EEDTs, which can be built with great simplicity and allows the distributed-load detection using one single device. A standard polymer-based micro-fabrication process will be employed to ensure its disposability and affordability. The technical approach includes 1) experimental investigation of the device performance as a function of its geometry and electrolyte properties; 2) development of a theoretical framework for quantification of the device performance; 3) its optimization for ultra-high spatial resolution and ultra-high load resolution; and 4) its adaptation for biomaterial and biological tissue investigations.

The results of this research will enable the development of miniaturized distributed-load sensors for biomedical, surgical, robotics, and manufacturing applications. Disposable, affordable, high-performance EEDT devices will revolutionize the intelligent systems and instruments, manufacturing equipment, and robots that rely on the functionality of distributed-load detection. Consequently, systems incorporating EEDT devices will be used to diagnose diseases at early stages, improve surgical outcomes, shorten development time, increase the manufacturing quality of viscoelastic materials and biomaterials, allow industrial automation, and save lives by enabling robotic operations in hazardous environments.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding on how the performance of a polymer-based microfluidic device with Electrolyte-Enabled Distributed Transducers (EEDT) depends on the device design parameters. A standard fabrication process is employed to fabricate this device for its disposability and affordability. Different versions of the device are developed for examining its material testing, biomedical and robotics applications. The key outcomes of the intellectual merit are: 1) the static and dynamic performance of the device is theoretically and experimentally studied and the correlation of the key design parameters to the key performance parameters is established; 2) complex interplay between the electrolyte (liquid) and the polymer microstructure was numerically studied; 3) a testing method built-upon this device is developed for measuring the viscoelasticity of soft materials and soft biological tissues; 4) a two-dimensional (2D) device is utilized to conduct tumor detection among  mouse breast tumor tissues ex vivo and mouse pancreatic tumor tissues in vivo; 5) based on a one-dimensional (1D) device with a built-in probe, a conformal indentation testing method is developed that allows measuring the viscoelasticity of soft materials with curved surface (as an example, human and porcine costal cartilage are measured); 6)  the feasibility of using the device for arterial pulse signal measurements and hence monitoring the cardiovascular system is demonstrated. All the key scientific findings have been published and disseminated in different journals and conferences in different fields (ASME, IEEE and BMES). Overall, this research has generated ten journal papers and two journal papers under review, and multiple conference papers and presentations.

This research project has helped in training five graduate students among whom three students have graduated with their PhD degrees, and challenged ten undergraduate students (five of them were financially supported by REU) and 12 high school students. The work conducted by the undergraduate students has led to journal and conference publications. One undergraduate minority student moved on to biomedical engineering graduate program. Some of the high school students have moved to pursuing STEM majors in college.  Based on this research, monthly lab demonstrations have been held for local high school students.


Last Modified: 07/12/2018
Modified by: Julie Zhili Hao
